Posts.Content: Shachar wrote: Hello, everyone!   I'm a 37 year old mother of five children ages 16-8.  My journey began around a year ago.  I had noticed some breast milk leaking from my left breast.  It wasn't a lot so I wasn't too concerned, but I had also been having migraines that had come on suddenly, blurred vision, dizziness, and would see spots.  The doctor decided it was migraines and nothing to worry about so off I went.  This was my first doctor's visit in five years because I stay in good shape and am very active in martial arts.  The dizziness continued along with the leaking breast milk, and now I had a small (maybe marble size) lump in the bottom portion of my left breast that got larger in the middle of my cycle and then shrunk near menstruation.  Back to the doctor I went and this time he determined that it was probably fibro adenomas since I have fibrous breast tissue and do drink a lot of caffeine.  That sounded good, nothing to worry about.  Three months later the lump was still changing size but was getting painful at its largest, which was now about the size of a jaw breaker.  In addition, I found two lumps under my armpit.  It was painful enough to use a heating pad to make it better at times.  Third trip to the doctor and he still said it was probably fibroadenomas but let's just get a mammogram done to make sure.   As I stood in the waiting room, the receptioninst left the window wide open as she called and told them that "(my name) needs to be scheduled for a mammogram for fibroadenomas".  The whole waiting room was looking so I basically ducked and ran.  Not having insurance, not wanting to ever go back and have my business broadcasted, and still thinking it was fibroadenomas (so not use in spending that $400 on a diagnositic mammogram) I decided to blow it off.  Again. It has been six or eight months now.   A few weeks ago my entire left breast turned red and felt warm to the touch for two days.  It was very painful to the touch and I noticed another lump to the left of my sternum in addition to the two in the armpit.  Both breasts had gotten larger to where I went up a cup size (now that was NICE!) but then the left has continued to grow beyond the right.  It is noticeably larger and hangs lower.  The left nipple also is being drawn in on the bottom side, like it is being pulled into a pucker. Time to quit blowing it off.  At least half of my left breast is now "the lump".  It feels like it is the size of a lemon and is hard.  It doesn't get smaller or larger throughout my menstrual cycle anymore.  I bawled on the front porch yesterday and my husband made the appointment for the mammogram for 3 PM at our local hospital.  Friday the 13th. The tech went out to confer with the doctor after the first shots, and more were taken with different "paddles" to focus in on the lump.  I got to see it on the film and named it "Patrick" from Spongebob because it looked like a big starfish. (Was trying to stay humerous).  Then they sent me over to have an ultrasound done and took more pictures and measurements.  The radiiologist came in and examined me, and looked like she was about to cry.  She told me not to leave here today thinking I had "something bad" but it wasn't cysts or fibroadenomas.  It was either A) scar tissue over an old ruptured cyst or B) let's not talk about that until after the biopsy is done.  In addition to Patrick, there were several other dark circles around it that were measured but not mentioned.  Lymph nodes?  Cysts? So next week I will be going for an ultrasound guided biopsy.  I have no idea how much this is going to cost but they said they would make payment arrangements with me.  I spent the rest of the day just bawling like I have never bawled before, on and on.  I still hope for the best but can they really tell me that scar tissue would somehow affect my lymph nodes for this period of time?   Sometimes you just know.   If I had gone 6-8 months ago would it have made a difference?  I don't know since the lymph nodes were present then as well.  Just hoping for the best and don't know where else to turn, so here I am.  I do have an excellent, supportive husband and good friends but they haven't BTDT got the t-shirt.  Before now, I have never given much thought to breast cancer.  Either way, this will forever change my life and how I look at things. Dx 4/23/2012, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IIIC, Grade 1, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2012 05:34PM Shachar wrote: Thank you both.  My left breast externally does look different from my right at this point, so I thought maybe that was what it meant.  They asked a lot of questions as to things that may have caused scar tissue like breast implants, previous breast surgery, trauma, etc.  Nothing.  I have so much to learn but now I'm just having a hard time walking past the bathroom mirror looking at my breast without thinking "what did I ever do to you?"  It seems that my whole family has lost it.  My mom calls to tell me that I should have a full masectomy and not consider a lumpectomy because it's so much safer, and I am not even diagnosed!  My husband says he can't even think about living without me as if I have already been handed a death sentence.  This is just insanity and I am SOOO very sorry that I have never taken much time to look beyond the pink ribbons and considered just how much this disease impacts people, friends, families.  No matter what, from now on I will.
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2012 07:36PM Shachar wrote: Thank you everyone!  Yes, my mother had added me to every prayer chain she knows of.  I believe in prayer, but I want to really wait and see what is what before we include too many people in this adventure.   My husband is typically pretty solid but I guess he had a moment.  To top it off, I have been extremely sick since yesterday afternoon with some stomach bug/body aching/head pounding issue.  What I mistook for shock fog was probably the beginning of it.  I know stress makes us more prone to getting sick, but this has sucked.  This is the time I want my head to be in the game, to research like crazy, to be focused...and I've been stuck on the couch slurping Sprite and sleeping.   My oldest daughter also came home sick this morning with the same issue so we spent an hour watching the Waltons together.  Not being able to get up and go to work, clean my house, take care of the kids, cook dinner, or reach out and touch someone has been miserable and I had that helpless feeling that nearly triggered an anxiety attack with everything else going on.  Fortunately, I was too sick to feel pathetic for too long and I feel asleep.  Unfortunately, a fever induced sleep produced weird dreams that don't go well with worry over an upcoming biopsy, lol, especially after viewing lumpectomy pictures on my cell phone.  Not recommended.  I am SO hoping I'm back to feeling 100% in the morning so I can go out and conquer life again.  I can't handle too much more of this feeling out of control with a foggy head!  :)
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2012 06:59AM Shachar wrote:
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2012 09:46AM Shachar wrote:
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 05:19PM Shachar wrote: Thanks for checking in on me, everyone!  I seem to be so tired, and am sure it is just emotional stress.  Yesterday I went for a four hour drive so I wouldn't break down in front of the kids, and the time alone was good for me.  Tomorrow is "the day", should get the results by the afternoon.  I already applied for a payment plan at the hospital and they said I would qualify.  I didn't have to put a dime down for the $5k biopsy.  They also told me that, based upon our huge family size, I would actually qualify for a special medicaid program for women with breast and cervical cancer!  I couldn't believe that, but I guess it's true.  Not only that, but they would back-pay any unpaid bills for 3 months...covering the cost of the biopsy.  I've never been on public assistance, so in a way I am humiliated but in another way I am relieved that if it is malignant I will not have to choose my treatment based upon what I can afford.  I just barely made the cut off for income limit.  I haven't paid into health insurance because I am very healthy and rarely ever go to the doctor, and took out only an accident policy.  Not so bright looking back, but I can't change that now. Still hoping for the best and mentally planning for the worst!  I had my pitty party last night, so I should be good for another week.
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2012 02:15PM Shachar wrote:
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2012 09:14PM Shachar wrote:
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2012 11:15PM Shachar wrote: Thank you, Bouncing Betties.  I don't even want to put my other fears out there anymore, not to give them too much attention and maybe then they wont ever materialize.  :)  I pray your CT results are free and clear! BIG HUG right back, Sheila!
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: May 1, 2012 10:21PM Shachar wrote:
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 11:59AM Shachar wrote: Thank you, Carpediem.   It is gorgeous weather outside here in Florida and I'm sitting inside just feeling down.   I really need to take your advice and go out to do something, anything.   I just keep wondering if there is any hard, very large and hard feeling scar tissue of an irregular star-fish type shape that involves the lymph nodes under the armpit that is benign? And do all (any) radiologists actually come back in after viewing the ultrasound pictures and the mammogram pictures taken by the techs to do a physical exam themselves before picking up the ultrasound wand and looking even more? The looks on their faces, my husband telling me it's probably nothing at all and wanting to believe him.  Not knowing is the worst because I'm ready to face whatever it is or just get back to life and forget it.  I think today is my angry day, lol.  :)  Then I read posts of you strong women going through agonizing treatments and I tell myself I have not a single thing to complain about.
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2012 02:43PM Shachar wrote: Thank you, Elaine.  I really need to be patient (not one of my better qualities, for sure) and quit acting like such a spaz.  I am about to go meet a friend for coffee and I told her if she didn't have any problems right now to make some up because, strangely enough, that seems to help.   Hearing about other people and trying to help them takes my mind off of myself. Ali, I am so sorry you are having a rough day today.  It's a bit hard to put our best foot forward with this.   It sounds like you for sure need one of my pills and also a coffee night.  Come on, let's go!
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 07:04PM Shachar wrote:
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: May 1, 2012 08:01PM Shachar wrote: Thank you, Marie.  I'm sorry, I got results and then ran for the "Just diagnosed" section.    I'm rather enjoying myself in planning for my future breasts.  I wish I could have designed them from the beginning, hee hee.  I'm a B/C and I'm thinking about going D.  Just because I can..... When life hands you lemons, made "D" size boobs.   You guys are great.
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 08:43PM Shachar wrote: You guys are really wonderful and I cannot tell you how much this board already means to me.  Today is "fog" day, just in a funk and drained, probably from all the crying over the last two days.  How pathetic is that?  No diagnosis and tears from someone who almost never cries over anything.  So today is just empty. Yesterday was twisted humor day, and Friday you would think I was planning a funeral.  What gets to me is my kiddos.   I look at them and I wonder, will I see their graduations?  Their weddings?  Will they grow up without me?  Will they be okay?  And then I get onto myself for the melodrama when there's nothing even known yet.  I don't even have PMS.  I do have a strong faith in God and know that I will praise him even in this storm.  Thank you, thank you, thank you all for your words and wisdom and I keep you all in my prayers.
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2012 08:02PM Shachar wrote: Thank you everyone.  I am very thankful to have found this board with wonderful and supportive people.  I try not to give myself the diagnosis when I shouldn't but it is hard.  Having been in the medical field for awhile, it's true that information is not always a good thing.  I ask myself how it could be scar tissue that affects the lymph nodes.  And if it's in the lymph nodes, it must already be at least stage 3.  And considering the size....I need to just quit thinking and analyzing, and quit getting my google degree.   The doctor is supposed to call me Monday with a time for the biopsy.  The mammogram was done late in the afternoon Friday so there was apparently little time to read it and confer with my doctor.   My doctor does not have the written report yet, but said he will Monday.  I plan to get it and over analyze it.  I feel like I have a mood disorder now.  I'll be crying my eyes out one minute, grieving over something I haven't yet lost and then laughing the next minute or pretending it isn't real.  I want to be with friends, I want to be alone.  I am so glad to be with people who understand, and I hope I can be there as much for all of you.
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2012 01:27PM - edited Apr 16, 2012 01:46PM by Shachar Thank you, guys.  Today has been a good day because I got to go back to work and have lots of distractions.  I was able to go to the hospital this morning and get a copy of the written report in addition to my ultrasound and mammogram immages on CD.  There is some good news in that it is smaller than what I suspected.  It feels huge but it seems that it isn't that big.  The report says that it is "an ill-defined highly lobulated mass at 3 o'clock which measures 2.3 x 2.5 cm".  I guess I don't understand why, on the ultrasound, it also showed measurements of two other masses.  One was 1.5 cm and the other was .7 cm at the largest.  The small one was round but the other was just as odd in shape as the one mentioned in the report.  So maybe I am feeling two different ones in there?  My biopsy is scheduled for Friday at 9 AM with the same radiologist.  That makes me feel more comfortable because I like her.  I guess now I am in for the long wait, but that may be good to let it sink it a little over the next four days.  Thank you all for caring and sharing. Also, it says BIRADS 4 and I have "architectural distortion".  Is that a polite way of saying "this chick has a deformed breast"?  LOL.  I can also see why it is pulling the nipple down, it is pretty close to the front of my breast and looks to be right up under the nipple.
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2012 01:20PM Shachar wrote: That sounds hopeful, then, that I wont have to face another weekend sitting around wondering.  I'm not sure what I will do differently if I don't know, but it would be nice to go celebrate "this looks good".  Meanwhile, I have begun to massage the lump with lotion.  Yeah, I know it's not doing a thing but I have to feel like I am doing something.  Maybe if I massage enough it will just go away or at least shrink, like using a giant eraser.  Right now I am in a good place, like "it is what it is".  The view is nice from the top of the roller coaster.  Two more days!
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: May 6, 2012 01:59PM - edited May 6, 2012 02:00PM by Shachar Hello everyone!  I'm not sure yet if I will be on the May roster or if it will be early June but there isn't yet a June thread.  I go back to the BS on the 14th after consult with a 2nd PS on the 11th.  Hopefully this will be a winning combination and we can schedule a day for surgery the 14th.  Nervous but just ready to get this thing out of my body....so hoping for an end of May surgery date.
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: May 12, 2012 04:37PM Shachar wrote: To those of you who have recently had surgery and are recovering, I hope you all feel better soon!  Thank you for sharing with those of us waiting.
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: May 28, 2012 04:42PM Shachar wrote: Thank you, guys.  Yes, DH is awesome and I couldn't ask for any better.  I FINALLY got my pathology reports, which were supposed to be back on Wednesday but nobody ever called.  I know my BS was going on vacation for two weeks but I went to see the PS on Friday and just picked up my own pathology report then.  At its largest my mass was 7 cm and I had 11/16 positive nodes.  The good news is that they got clear margins in the breast all the way around and that there was 1 clear node at the highest node and the four lowest nodes.   So I know it's stage 3 but unknown where on the spectrum since nobody has bothered to even call me.  I plan on getting a new onc soon anyway, one that is closer to home.  They were kind enough to send me a letter in the mail of my upcoming appointment dates with the onc.  Such personal service, lol. I wish everyone the best in the upcoming days for surgeries!  I think the toughest part, at least for me, is the pesky drains.  I got the right one out Friday since it was doing about 30cc/day but the left (where they removed the nodes) was still around 120cc/day.  Currently the left is down to about 60cc/day so almost there.
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: May 14, 2012 01:50PM Shachar wrote: It is confirmed that I am scheduled for BMX this Friday, the 18th.  I'm glad that I don't have too long to stress out about it.  The surgeon said I should be able to go home Sunday.  Total surgery time should be 1.5-2 hours for the general surgeon and then 1.5 hours for the plastic surgeon.  I'm glad to be getting this lump out, but also nervous.
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: May 17, 2012 08:22PM Shachar wrote: Surgery is tomorrow and will begin in about 12 hours from now.  Oddly, I'm not really freaking out and have a peace about it.  Tomorrow morning might be a different issue, but I'm just anxious to get it over with.  PET scan revealed no mets, so it will be nice after tomorrow to say that I am "cancer free" when everything is removed.  My bag is packed (with all of the supplies suggested on this board, thank you!) and I am ready to roll.  Thank you for the well wishes, and I will post when I can.  Time to kick some cancer tail!
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: May 22, 2012 07:11PM Shachar wrote: Hello everyone!  I'm BACK!  Had BMX on the 18th as scheduled with axillary node dissection.  The PET scan results came back before surgery that at least two lymph nodes on the left side were involved, one at 1.5 cm and the other at 1.0 cm.  My surgeon took all of the lymph nodes, but he said he doesn't know how many were taken nor how many were involved until pathology comes back.  He did say that, based upon the PET scan done prior, that they got it all out.  Yippee!  Also wont know how big the lump was until pathology comes back and I don't really care, just glad it is all gone now and they were able to save all of my skin except the nipples and areolas.  I spent all of the 18th in a morphine drip coma, talking to people on the phone but falling asleep just seconds into the conversation.  I don't remember being wheeled out of pre-op or down to surgery because they gave me IV meds prior.  It sounds like I was being comical, telling them that I looked like a bag of jiffy pop with that foil head covering they put on my head.  My mom said I asked them if they were planning full head radiation or what?  DH said that I dropped my cell phone just before they wheeled me out and I was saying as I went down the hall, "Where is my cell phone?"  As soon as I woke up from surgery I said, "Where is my cell phone?"  I woke up searching the blankets for it frantically. DH broke the news to me that they couldn't put in the spectrum one-step implants because my pec muscles were too tight.   Due to a knee injury in karate I had been working out on the total gym instead, working those pec muscles good before I was diagnosed.  He said they had a hard time even getting TEs behind them, no fluid added at all.  So, I look like a small A cup right now.  The PS did an excellent job closing me back up, using some type of purple glue so it looks like thin little lines.  Well, the right is pretty small.  It will all be under a new areaola but the left is larger and I will probably have a two inch scar to the outside of the left nipple.  Honestly, I don't even care.  I'm just glad surgery is over even though I am looking at another one for the exchange. Surgery Friday, drugged up Saturday until Saturday evening and then extreme claustrophobia in my hospital room.  My view was of a wall out the window and the room got very, very small.  I also was tired of being so drugged so I asked them to discontinue my morphine drip Saturday morning and put me on pills instead.  I was so nauseated on the morphine that I wasn't eating.  The worst part was the anxiety from feeling "boxed in", so I popped an ativan and DH took me for a stroll in the wheel chair while it kicked in.  That helped a lot and I got fortunate to have a nurse on the night shift who also had anxiety issues so she understood. Came home Sunday, still nauseated and throwing up.  I started feeling weak and totally run  down, getting dehydrated.   I felt like all I could do was lay there, so I quit taking narcotic pain meds Sunday evening hoping that I would be able to eat when the nausea wore off.  A friend then gave me a phenergan pill for the nausea and I came to life again!  My doc called in Phenergan Monday morning and it was awesome to be able to eat again! Today I have been awesome, four days out.  I've been walking all over the house, straightened up my bedroom, dressed myself completely after taking a bath (waist deep only),  and feel human again!  I have removed all of the surgical tape (PS said I could when I went home) and am happily wearing a sports bra with nursing pads stuck in them so I can apply tons of neosporin to the incision.   I had three drains, two on the left and one on the right, but one of the left drains never did drain anything so they took it out before I left the hospital.  After the nurse warned me that it would probably hurt really bad, and I made her promise to go slow and stop if I asked her to, I didn't feel a thing. I am back on the pain meds but taking only half of the 750 mg hydrocodone every 5-6 hours with 6 mg of phenergan (cut into 4ths) and a regular 500 mg Tylenol.  This seems to work for me, and I take an ativan in the evening to relax.  I am getting back to myself, have pretty good range of motion and can lift both arms straight up in the air plus out to the side.  My left arm does feel a little weaker than the right.  My kids come in four times a day and make me to my arm excercises.  Friday, 7 days after surgery, I go to the PS to get my drains out and get my first fill.  He thinks I will be able to do 100 cc but we will see.   Today is the best I have felt since surgery and it's nice to be getting back to feeling like myself. When I looked at my incisions on my breasts for the first time Sunday afternoon I had to sit down on the floor because I felt like I was going to pass out.  Monday I was ready to look again and it wasn't so bad, I knew it would all be okay.  Then I let DH seem them and he said they are still the most beautiful breasts he had ever seen, kissing each one.   I sure love that guy!  He has been my rock and has waited on my hand and foot, and knowing that he thinks my breasts look okay has made me more accepting of it as well.  I think that was always my biggest fear, and now it is gone. Sending hugs and well wishes to my other sisters who are recovering and  to those who will soon be having their surgeries.  (((HUGS)))
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: May 11, 2012 02:57PM Shachar wrote: That's funny, Melissa!  I went to the PS today and I will be doing BMX and immediate recon with the Sentrum adjustable implants.  He siad if I don't like them then we can always take them out like a tissue expander and exchange them for the memory gel silicone.  Tentatively, I am scheduled for next Friday, the 18th.   His office with confirm with the BS when I go back there this Monday.  It seems that this is the winning team.  I'm nervous but at the same time, I can't wait to get this thing out of me.   I am doing SSM, so nipple and areola recon will be down the road.  I appreciate the posts of all those who have gone before to help the rest of us prepare, and I will do the same.  I really don't know what I would do without this board. ((HUGS))

Posts.Title: PET scan results Shachar Moderators

Posts.Content: Shachar wrote: Hello everybody.  I got my results back from the PET scan today, one day before surgery.  There are two involved lymph nodes, measuring 1.4 cm and 1 cm, and I have two ovarian cysts (one each side) that are benign.  My confusion is this regarding the left affected breast: "Promininent diffuse abnormal activity in the left breast compatible with residual left breast neoplasm and postsurgical changes".  That's it.  No lump measurement!  What in the world does this mean?  I have been worried because the onc thinks I could have a 3-5 cm lump in there (hoping for under 5 cm myself) and now there is no measurement in this report.    Why would ever other lump in my body be measured but not this one?  Any help greatly appreciated. On a good note, no mets.  Dx 4/23/2012, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IIIC, Grade 1, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: PET scan results Shachar Moderators

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2012 04:44PM Shachar wrote: Shayne, I couldn't do marijuana because when I tried it in high school it made me very paranoid and then stressed because I was paranoid, lol!  Don't feel bad about needing something to help right now.  I am taking Ativan right now, half a pill to a whole pill (1 mg) at night.  It seems like that's when it creeps up on me too, starting like a knot in the pit of my stomach. At first I needed a whole, but now half works just fine when I do need to take it.  I have managed one night without it completely.  Woot woot!  A whole pill makes me too groggy the next day and I don't like that feeling, either.  I'm a night owl anyway and any stress will keep me up until the crack of dawn. The way I look at it, I would rather have to take something temporarily that will help me sleep to keep my immune system healthy and to prevent worse anxiety than try to be tough and get sick.  I don't think I'll have to be on it for years, just enough to get through the not knowing how bad this lump is for me phase.  I'm not a drinker, so it is nice to have something to help take the edge off.  Those medications were made for situations like this.
Posts.Title: Help with Anxiety Shayne Shirlann

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2012 01:30PM Shachar wrote: I had general anesthesia in surgery before during a pregnancy.  My voice was hoarse for the day after the surgery and my throat a little soar, but that was it.  As I paramedic, I have intubated several people and it's highly unlikely that an anesthesiologist, who has done thousands of intubations, would damage your vocal cords...if that makes you feel any better!   We used a tool called a laryngescope that has light on the end of it.  With that, you can see down the throat and visualize the vocal cords.  That is actually where we aim for, right between the vocal cords.  The ET tube passes through without touching the cords and then a small balloon is inflated beneath the cords to hold it in place.  This balloon protects your airway from any fluids going into your lungs.  The anesthesiologist will ask you to open your mouth and look in to see if you will be easy to intubate or not.  It is more common for the top teeth to be injured during intubation than anything else.  I hope this helps!  You will be asleep and not feel it at all.  I would share your concerns with them, though, to make sure they are extra extra careful.

Posts.Title: Scared out of my mind Shayne rocklizard

Posts.Content: Shachar wrote: Sleep did not come well at all last night, until I invited my friend Ativan along.  A year ago, when this all began, I began having full blown anxiety attacks and so I was prescribed 30 Ativan.  I still had 25 left (hate taking medication and just dealt with it), so they have been put to good use at night since Friday.  The truth be known, I felt like a hypochondriac and put off going to the doctor for a good 6-8 months before finally going a year ago.  My best friend talked me into it, having lived through treatment for a pituitary gland tumor.  I was having the massive headaches, blurred vision, confusion, the room would tilt, eyes about to pop out of my head, seeing shadows and flashing lights, and then the left breast leaking milk.  The head symptoms would come on for a week and then disappear for a month or more.  My menstrual cycles were becoming irregular and much lighter.   I would also have anxiety that came out of nowhere, for no reason at all, worrying about crazy stuff like bills when they were all paid! (Hence the Ativan script, and another for migraines that remained unfilled).  I have no anxiety/depression history, so this was very disturbing to me and I was just convinced that I had brain tumor.  I knew something was wrong, but didn't want to be that person who had invented issues and visited the doctor constantly with invented symptoms. I was happy for a "migraine" diagnosis and all of my hormone levels checked out normal so no MRI. Hence, the long, long time between my visits when I discovered the lump and then watching it grow, turn my skin red and warm, having lots of pain with it, feeling the lymph nodes enlargen,and having my entire breast turn hard as a rock before softening again.   Now, I think too much.  I have googled too many ultrasound breast images and what I have doens't look like anything at all benign.  But that isn't even what bothers me the most right now.  I can clearly see the mass they measured at 2.5 cm, but there is one that looks the same...long, dark, black, and irregular (not cysts like, more like a scorpion that curls and twists) not far from it that they measured at 1.84 cm to be exact.  And then there are one or two, more roundish but still irregular and "dished" like pac-man's mouth that measure at .7 cm and .5 cm.  That may be the same one from different angles, but it is obviously against the chest wall and attached/imbedded slightly. And I wonder, why have they failed to mention this in the report?  Do they biopsy the biggest one first and then dump it all on you at once? That you have multiple masses?  I hate to even think that way and maybe I shouldn't have gotten the films.  I wish there was a way to upload the picture of them both on here. So I am going to be honest with my board friends because I wouldn't breathe a word of this out loud in real life.  I am terrified that I am going to be told that I have stage IV breast CA with METS.  I know this is not the right attitude and having my imagination run wild, maybe that is normal.  I don't know because I have never been through this.   I just had to "say" it somewhere, to acknowledge that fear.  I have begun to journal what I feel to get it out, so I don't have to burden anyone IRL with it.  I think this started with a question before my pitty party.   Yes, it did.   Did any of your doctors withhold information until they had solid evidence?  As in, seeing more masses but reporting only one and then dropping the bomb later when it was obvious from the start?  Contrary to all indications, I was quite mentally stable before.    I'm good now.  This sucks and I will probably feel very foolish for posting this when the biopsy results come back. Dx 4/23/2012, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IIIC, Grade 1, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Do they withhold information? Shachar SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2012 10:31PM Shachar wrote: I appreciate all of you, and I promise that I am not always (never) like this.  IRL I am the rock that others come to with a crisis, and to others IRL I still look that way.   I just had to get those fears out there, acknowledge them so I could move past them.   For fourteen years of my life I was a paramedic.   I was there to hold the hands of those sick and suffering,  I saved lives and I held the hands of some who died.  In all that I did, I tried to be as honest with my patients as I could.   But...I know some were not.  Some would tell patients it was all okay when it wasn't.   I was the one who would tell them "it is serious, but you are in good hands and I'm not going to let you die".  I meant it.  That's the doctor I want. I could tell you a lot about emergency medicine, but know next to nothing about oncology and that scares me.  Oncology is the one field I said that I could never work in.  I do feel better this evening, talked to my aunt who is a breast cancer survivor from two years ago and 30 minutes away. She offered to throw me a "scarf" party, lol!  I asked her if I could borrow her synthetic breast for the biopsy tomorrow, planning on putting it in my bra as a third.  The humor has helped.   Laugh the tears away.

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2012 12:34AM - edited Apr 19, 2012 12:36AM by Shachar I have already developed a game plan!   I am going to take a Xanax, drink a bottle of wine, and then put myself on ice to be shipped over for the biopsy, hee hee!  Yes, no more Youtube videos for sure and I appreciate all of the experiences so I can know what to expect.  The chewing and drilling would  have been a shocker, as would that giant metal pipe with "the claw" at the other end coming at me.  I would have told them that they had the wrong patient because I only signed up for the needle biopsy! My lump looks really anterior on the mammogram and ultrasound pictures, right behind the nipple (probably why it's tugging on it). I'm going to be a little upset if they chew my nipple off or suck it into that machine.  Okay, I can do this now.  Sounds pain free! Positive thoughts, will keep you in prayer tomorrow and wishing you an easy biopsy.
Posts.Title: U/S guided core needle biopsy? Shachar Shachar

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2012 06:28PM - edited Apr 21, 2012 06:29PM by Shachar You guys all helped so much!!!  I knew what to expect  and that eased my worries.  Since they didn't let the hubby go back in there with me, I was especially thankful that I knew what was going to happen.  I barely felt the lidocaine shot at all.  The let me hear the sound of the core biopsy thingie (sorry, not sure what to call it) and said it would sound like a stapler, which did.   My aunt had told me that I would by lying on my stomach with by breast dangling through a hole in the table, so I was pleasantly surprised when that did not happen!  I actually got to lie on my back but slightly over on my right side wedged with cushions.  I had to hold my left arm up, and I used it to block my view of what they were doing.  They went in on the left side of my left breast.  During the second "click" I felt what was like a bee sting on my left nipple.  The radiologist said that they were deeper, well below the nipple, but I think the blob is attached to the nipple and it nicked a nerve.  Didn't feel a thing for the other two.  They inserted a "clip" in my left breast where they removed tissue, a small piece of titanium the size of a grain of sand, and then the did a mammogram to make sure it showed up.   That mammogram was nothing like the diagnostic one, no squeeze to it at all.  Easy breasy!  Knowing what to expect made that possible and I wanted to shout out a big THANK YOU!!!
Posts.Title: U/S guided core needle biopsy? Shachar Shachar

Posts.Content: Shachar wrote: They finally got my results back at 4:30 today and I managed to get there on two wheels before they closed.  The doc came in and told me he knew that I already knew from our last conversation.  He seemed pleased with the type of cancer, and said it was easier to treat but it is all still foreign to me and I have no clue.  I hope some of you will.  Infiltrating Ductal Carcinoma (Grade II), Nottingham HIstologic Grade: 6, Nuclear pleomorphism: 2, Mitotic count: 1.  E-cadherin imunohistochemical stain is positive confirming the ductal origin of the carcinoma.  Prognostic immunohistochemical stains were performed and scored using computer assisted Image Analysis by the VIAS with the following results: Estrogen Receptor: 67% of cells are immunoreactive Progesterone Receptor: 67% of cells are immunoreactive HER-2/neu: Negative (+1) FISH not performed     I guess that would explain initially why the lump increased during ovulation and decreased during my menstrual cycle, seeing that it is "fueled" by hormone levels.  I am just numb, but not shocked.  DH is taking it harder than me, because I think now it is a reality for him whereas for me I already knew the day I decided it was time for the mammogram.  We have told the kids, and they are doing okay.  We told them there will be treatments but we can do this as a family and we will get through it.  Ativan has helped me feel a little detached from it all right now, floating on a soft cloud of "whateverness".  My doctor also doubled my Welbutrin dose so I should be good to go.  They are making an appointment with the surgeon for me but I hope they don't expect me to schedule for surgery right away.  I need to take time, study, make informed decisions, and speak to the oncologist first. Okay, I will quit rambling.  Here I am. Dx 4/23/2012, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IIIC, Grade 1, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 11:27PM - edited Apr 22, 2012 11:28PM by Shachar Yes, that was it, Marie.  She said they would be up under me doing what they needed to do during the biopsy, so I was checking the table out for holes and didn't see any.  I found it odd that nobody here had mentioned what I thought was a pretty big deal, and was so glad I wasn't dangling!  (I was a bit concerned there wouldn't be enough to hang through the hole).  Anybody had any issues with sharp jolts of electricity shooting through the same arm on the biopsy side afterwards?  Just started in last night, traveling to either my thumb or my pinky. I figured maybe it is the tissue in my breast healing or something, but a little odd.  It only happens with arm movement, not just sitting still.
